Part E | Sellers decisions and the supply curve

Part E is about how market power changes the firm's decisions and how these decisions impact society. So far we've examined how to coordinate groups to minimize opportunity cost. In Part A we motivated this search using the realization that minimizing opportunity cost can make everyone better off simultaneously. In Part B we showed that in some cases markets can be an effective coordination device. In Part C we showed that externalities undermine the efficiency of markets but that we could correct this type of market failure using correctly calibrated Government Policies. In Part D we introduced game theory to help understand the strategic interaction that leads to market failure around Public Goods and Common Resources. We even developed some tools like voting and enforceable permits which can go a long way to minimizing market failure.

So far we've relied on loose models of why buyers and sellers choose to interact. In Part A we introduced buyers' preferences with the demand curve and sellers' costs with the supply curve. Before investigating where buyers' preferences come from, in Part E we make the turn to examine the seller's incentives.

We first start with the production function. Labor inputs generate output. Inputs are costly. As we increase inputs we increase output but we also increase cost. This relationship between quantity and costs gives us our core cost measures: Average Total Cost (ATC) and Marginal Cost (MC).

We assume that seller's aim to maximize their Profits, simply Total Revenue minus Total Cost. And we found that the solution to the Firm's Profit Maximization Problem is to set quantity where MC = MR. The shape of MC depends on the shape of the production function. The shape of MR depends on how much power the firm exerts over the market. Part E is about how this market power changes the firm's decisions and how these decisions impact society.

Videos

Part E Episode 1 (labeled as Tutorial 5.1) introduces the costs of production, similar to what we covered in class.

Part E Episode 2 (labeled as Tutorial 5.2) examines perfect competition from the firm's perspective, generating the supply curve.

Part E Episode 3 (labeled as Tutorial 5.3) examines the monopolist.

Reading

Reading is broken into two clusters. Cluster 1 is covered on MiniExam E1. Cluster 2 is covered on MiniExam E2. Start Part E by skimming the reading to develop an understanding of the scope of what's being discussed.

Then once you've finished reading, take a look at the practice material, and use the text as a resource when you need help. This way, you know what's most important, get to practicing quickly, and know where to find help when you innevitably get stuck.

Cluster 1 | Ch. 13 Ch. 15 Ch. 16

Cluster 2 | Ch. 17 Ch. 18

Vignettes

Vignette E1 Solutions

Vignette E1 does Economic Sudoku, building intuition for the relationships between cost variables.

Vignette E2 Solutions

Vignette E2 covers the transition of a market from Monopoly to Perfect Competition. This requires understanding market structures and being able to describe the impacts of this change using the tools and methods developed in class.

Vignette E3

Vignette E3 extends the concepts and tools of game theory to examine markets with few sellers, Oligopoly, in which strategic interaction governs the solution to the firm's problem.

Demos

Demos are very similar to what you'll see on MiniExams E. This is a resource for you to use as you'd like. But here's my advice. Start by trying to solve the Demos on your own. Then once you've worked through everything as best you're able, use the video and solutions to check your work. You're more than welcome to watch this video first, but you're not going to catch your weak points as easily, which is the main point.

Demo E1 Solutions

Demo E1 discusses the impact of a subsidy in a perfectly competitive market in the long run.

Demo E2 Solutions

Demo E2 walks through a mathematical solution to the Monopolist and uses a lump sum tax to capture some profit.

Demo E3 Solutions

Demo E3 is adapted from a MiniExam from a previous semester and examines the market impact of a merger of two Duopolist firms.

Demo E4 Solutions

Demo E4 is adapted from Homework from a previous semester and examines a subsidy in two regulatory environments.

MiniExams E

If you understand the concepts and do the work in the Vignettes and Demos, you're going to be in good shape on the MiniExam.
